titleInfo.title: Letter, W.A. Harrison in Harrodsburg, Ky., to J.G.M. Ramsey in Knoxville, Tenn. 1874 Nov. 12

mods.abstract: Rev. W.A. Harrison wrote to J.G.M. Ramsey on Nov. 12, 1874. He told J.G.M. he was sorry about his injury resulting from a fall from his horse. He discussed politics, expressing happiness in the outcome of recent elections which he saw as a Southern victory. He saw Ramsey as a prophet, as well as a historian. He agreed with Ramsey that the South would rise again and save our country. He saw this as one of God's works. He bemoaned the atrocities that had happened to the South. He thought the North would come around to the South's way of thinking. He thought the South would attain Constitutional freedom through the recent elections. He realized toward the end of his letter which was meant to be a "get well expression," that it had turned into a political ranting and apologized to Ramsey. He knew Ramsey would understand because of his mutual views.
